document_title: Lifelong Wheel Running Exercise and Mild Caloric Restriction Attenuate Nuclear EndoG in the Aging Plantaris Muscle
summary_full: This study investigated the effects of lifelong mild caloric restriction (CR) and wheel running exercise with CR (WR+CR) on caspase-independent apoptosis and heat shock proteins (HSPs) in aging rat skeletal muscle. The researchers hypothesized that these interventions would reduce age-induced increases in endonuclease G (EndoG) and apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF), while preserving HSP27 and HSP70 levels. They found that while aging increased nuclear EndoG levels, both CR and WR+CR significantly attenuated this increase. HSP27 protein content and phosphorylation were reduced with age but restored by CR and further enhanced by WR+CR. AIF and HSP70 levels were not significantly affected by the interventions. The findings suggest that CR and WR+CR attenuate age-associated apoptosis by preventing nuclear EndoG accumulation, with HSP27 signaling playing a key role in this protective mechanism.
key_findings: Aging significantly increases nuclear levels of the pro-apoptotic protein Endonuclease G (EndoG) in plantaris muscle.
Lifelong mild caloric restriction (8%) and wheel running exercise with caloric restriction significantly attenuate the age-induced increase in nuclear EndoG.
Aging decreases HSP27 protein content and its phosphorylation at Ser82, which are restored by caloric restriction and further increased by wheel running exercise with caloric restriction.
Apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF) and HSP70 protein levels were not significantly altered by aging or the interventions.
The protective effects of caloric restriction and exercise against age-related apoptosis in skeletal muscle appear to be mediated, at least in part, by the modulation of EndoG and HSP27 signaling.
future_research_fields: Investigating the direct role of HSP27 in mediating EndoG-activated apoptosis or cell death using genetic manipulation.
Examining the effects of lifelong exercise and caloric restriction on muscle atrophy, cellular function, and physical performance in relation to EndoG and HSP27.
Determining the precise molecular mechanisms by which HSP27 interferes with caspase-independent apoptotic signaling.
Comparing the efficacy of mild vs. moderate caloric restriction on caspase-independent apoptotic pathways in skeletal muscle.
Further exploring the potential role of AIF in age-related muscle apoptosis and its response to lifestyle interventions.
conclusions: Lifelong mild caloric restriction and wheel running exercise with caloric restriction effectively attenuate age-induced nuclear accumulation of EndoG in skeletal muscle. These interventions also upregulate HSP27 protein levels and phosphorylation, suggesting that HSP27 may act as an upstream protective mechanism against apoptosis and sarcopenia by modulating EndoG signaling.
impact_statement: This study reveals that lifelong exercise and caloric restriction can protect aging skeletal muscle from apoptosis by targeting specific molecular pathways, offering potential strategies for combating age-related muscle loss.
